utterances: But the administration is now arguing that by publishing classified reports on the Internet, WikiLeaks has jeopardized national security and the exercise of diplomacy.
The Department of Justice is considering legal charges against Assange.
Members of Congress are calling for legislation that would make it possible to crack down on organizations like WikiLeaks.
Evgeny Morozov, who blogs about the impact of the Internet on global politics, wonders what should be made of Clinton's speech today.

This basic impulse to promote Internet freedom abroad is contradicted by the wishes of American policymakers who don't want to save the Internet because it undermines the power of America and also threatens it in many ways.
It basically makes America look very hypocritical.
That same point is now being made by Vladimir Putin in Russia, as well as by other world leaders.
And reports that the U.S.
government has pressured companies to cut ties with WikiLeaks has given more fuel to WikiLeak supporters.

Sean Paul Cordell(ph), a threat researcher at Panda Security, has been chronicling how many WikiLeak supporters have joined in cyber attacks aimed at MasterCard and Visa, both of whom have suspended payments to WikiLeaks.
These, he says, are protestors who might otherwise have been demonstrating in the street.
What I kind of attribute it to is you don't have to stand in a picket line anymore and I think people realize that they can fight back with technology.
But this new turn in the pro WikiLeaks movement could also be problematic.
Marcia Hofmann says her organization, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, is disappointed to see the hack attacks on the websites.
This is a free speech debate and the best way to promote free speech is to continue to speak about things that you don't like.
And the worst thing to do is to shut somebody else down or silence them so that they can't be part of that debate, too.
The outcome of this fight is still uncertain.
Escalation by the United States and allied governments could radicalize the Internet freedom movement.
But confrontational tactics on the part of the WikiLeaks supporters could alienate some of those who may otherwise sympathize with them.
Tom Gjelten, NPR News, Washington.
One of the most popular classes at George Mason University is known as Zombies 101.
And in a moment, we'll pay a visit.
But first to South Korea, where on this Halloween Sunday, we asked reporter Doualy Xaykaothao for an audio tour of some of Seoul's spookiest places.
(Soundbite of drum)
On the grounds of Gyeongbokgung, perhaps the most popular of the royal palaces in Seoul, a ceremony to mark the change of guards is taking place.
About 155 years ago, in this exact month, Empress Myeongseong Hwang, or Queen Min, was apparently murdered by Japanese assassins.
Since then, there have been tales about how she returned and other ghost sightings.
We asked an elderly woman sitting nearby about ghosts.
Does she see ghosts?
(Through translator) She didn't see, but she can feel.
At this point, security guards are starting to gather, and one even winks with laughter, listening to our conversation.
So we approach him.
Have you ever heard anything or seen anything?
(Through translator) No, not at all.
But then, he starts talking about another guard, who saw moving lights on the palace grounds long ago.
(Foreign language spoken)
He says a security guard saw some white moving objects, but he feels the man probably just mistaken shadows behind windows as ghosts or something.
Who are the dead?
Anthropologist Dr. Laurel Kendall of the American Museum of Natural History in New York has been studying shamans, gods and ghosts in Korea for three decades.
She says ideally, the dead are ancestors, people who lived a long life surrounded by family.
The ghosts, however, are none of the above.
At the far end extreme of ultimate ghostness is this absolutely detached being.
And battle sights, of course, are full of ghosts, very haunted.
She says Korea has a history that many Koreans feel is deeply unresolved.
This is a divided country.
This is a country that has never effectively ended the war.
As long as the memories of people who left people in the other half of the country persists, then, yes, Korea is haunted both metaphorically and, in the shaman world, it becomes a literal haunting.

Some 144 years ago, not far from the Yanghwajin Foreign Cemetery in Seoul, where we're standing now, Christian missionaries were brutally murdered, then taken to the nearby Han River as a warning to the incoming French fleet.
Park Eun-mi(ph) and her friend Han Dong-man(ph) are Catholics, visiting the cemetery on this cold evening.
She says she's never seen a ghost, but believes in them.
(Foreign language spoken)
She says her friend goes to this deep mountain path, sits there and prays for the dead.
She says she sees spirits take rice because their hands leave imprints in the rice basket.
Oh, we start to get goose bumps, and didn't want to hear anymore.
So we scurried out of the cemetery before friendly, hungry Christian ghosts visited us.
As the sun began to set along the Han River, 67-year-old Ryu Seung-hwan(ph), our taxi driver, told us he absolutely does not believe in ghosts.
(Foreign language spoken)
He explains that in the West, although people do not ignore ghosts, they do not worship or seek them as Korean ancestors have.
He joked that if there were ghosts, then his two dead wives would have returned from their graves.
For NPR News, I'm Doualy Xaykaothao in Seoul.
Back in 1992, Bruce Springsteen was already overwhelmed by cable TV.
Confident as ever, Trump is defying polls showing he is highly disliked by supporters of other candidates.
That's what Rubio and Cruz hope to capitalize on while they slug it out to be Trump's last rival.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, Columbia, S.
C.
Exercise, eat right and get a little traveling.
That could be a mind and soul expanding experience.
But many college students here in the U.S.
don't take advantage of global study programs.
According to the Institute for International Education, only 1 percent of co-eds study abroad.
And of those, just over 3 percent are African-American.
But Bardoli Global wants to change that.
Just a year old, the program has already helped dozens of students of color travel overseas.
For more, we've got a Bardoli student.
He's Corey Woodard, a junior at Texas Southern University, headed to Kenya later this year.
Also, Anthony Jewett, founder and CEO of Bardoli Global.
Welcome, gentlemen.
Hi.
How are you doing?
So Anthony, where does the name come from?
Bardoli.
I'm a Morehouse Man, let's say that first off.
And soâ€¦
We've had many proud Morehouse men on this show.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I've listened over the years.
I'm proud to know.
We - in 1947, there was a very monumental meeting between Gandhi and three African-American educators who were Morehouse men themselves.
And they were all men who were mentors to Dr. King.
So in theological circles people say that Dr. King adopted the non-violent philosophy that made him so successful in his civil rights movement because of this meeting, you know.
And so our message is that a social change in a large scale for students of color can take place through increased inter-cultural exchange.
So we want to take what happened at Bardoli and make it global.
So why do you think the numbers of travelers overseas, in terms of black students, is so low?
